title: 103_hr1079
content: The "Immigration Document Fraud Prevention Act of 1993" requires the issuance of new identification cards for aliens. The Attorney General will issue new registration and identification cards to eligible aliens for employment verification purposes. The cards must be resistant to counterfeiting, allow employers to verify eligibility, and include a photo and identifying information. The new registration and identification cards for eligible aliens will contain a photograph and identifying information to allow employers to verify the bearer's identity. The cards will be issued to specific categories of nonimmigrants and aliens with temporary protected status or work authorization pending deportation determination. The new registration and identification cards for eligible aliens will contain a photograph and identifying information. The cards will specify the expiration date of work authorization, admission number, and alien file number. They will be valid for 10 years and must be reissued after the 10th anniversary. Employers can use the card to verify employment eligibility and inquire about work authorization status. The requirement or inquiry regarding immigration status will not be considered an unfair employment practice under section 274B of the Act. The implementation of the Act clarifies that inquiring about immigration status is not considered an unfair employment practice. Each authorized alien in the US must surrender their old alien registration card by October 1, 1994, and meet certain requirements to receive a new card, including proof of identity and payment of a fee not exceeding $75. The Attorney General may waive or reduce the fee if necessary. Notices of the fee requirement for new alien registration cards must be posted in post offices and Immigration offices during fiscal year 1994. Any old alien registration cards will be invalid as of October 1, 1997. The Social Security Act is amended to include the use of new registration and identification cards. The Immigration Document Fraud Prevention Act of 1993 requires the use of new registration and identification cards for housing assistance under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1980. The Immigration Document Fraud Prevention Act of 1993 mandates amendments to paragraphs regarding effective dates, replacing specific references with general ones, to take effect on October 1, 1997. The Immigration Document Fraud Prevention Act of 1993 mandates amendments to paragraphs regarding effective dates, replacing specific references with general ones, to take effect on October 1, 1997. Additionally, Section 4 of the Act prohibits the implementation of a national identity card. The new card described in section 2 shall not be a national identity card, not issued to US citizens, not required to be carried or presented except in specific circumstances. Section 1137(d) of the Social Security Act and section 214(d) of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1980 are referenced. The Attorney General will conduct an employer education program in collaboration with other agencies to inform employers about their responsibilities under the Immigration and Nationality Act. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 1994 and 1995 for this program. Stronger penalties for immigration fraud will be implemented. SEC. 7. STRONGER PENALTIES FOR IMMIGRATION FRAUD. Penalties for fraud and misuse of visas, permits, and other documents are increased from 5 to 10 years. Penalties for fraud related to identification documents are also increased from 5 to 10 years. SEC. 8. EMPLOYMENT ELIGIBILITY VERIFICATION DEMONSTRATION PROJECT. The Attorney General will continue the demonstration projects to determine the employment eligibility of authorized aliens through telephone and computation capabilities. A report on these projects must be submitted to Congress by October 1, 1994.
